metadata.subject: Mathematics
metadata.note: Florida's B.E.S.T. Standards for Mathematics were adopted by the State Board of Education on February 17, 2020

MA.8.NSO.1.1.title: Extend previous understanding of rational numbers to define irrational numbers within the real number system. Locate an approximate value of a numerical expression involving irrational numbers on a number line

clarifications.text: Instruction includes understanding that irrational numbers cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers.
Within this benchmark, the expectation is to approximate irrational numbers, including π, square roots and cube roots.
Instruction includes the understanding that the square root of a non-perfect square is irrational.

MA.8.NSO.1.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.NSO.1.2.title: Plot, order and compare rational and irrational numbers, represented in various forms

clarifications.text: Within this benchmark, the expectation is to represent numbers using integer exponents and radicals.
Instruction includes the use of the symbols <, > and =.
Instruction includes ordering and comparing rational and irrational numbers with and without the use of a number line.

MA.8.NSO.1.2.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.NSO.1.3.title: Extend previous understanding of the Laws of Exponents to include integer exponents. Apply the Laws of Exponents to evaluate numerical expressions and generate equivalent numerical expressions, limited to integer exponents and rational number bases, with procedural fluency

clarifications.text: Instruction includes an understanding of the inverse relationship between exponents and radicals.
Within this benchmark, it is the expectation to simplify monomial expressions with integer exponents.
Refer to Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality (Appendix D) and K-12 Glossary (Appendix A).

appendix_references: Appendix D: Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality

MA.8.NSO.1.4.title: Express numbers in scientific notation to represent and approximate very large or very small quantities. Determine how many times larger or smaller one number is compared to a second number

clarifications.text: Instruction includes understanding that a number written in scientific notation is represented as a × 10^n, where a is a number such that 1 ≤ |a| < 10 and n is an integer.
Within this benchmark, it is the expectation to translate numbers between scientific notation and standard form.

MA.8.NSO.1.4.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.NSO.1.5.title: Add, subtract, multiply and divide numbers expressed in scientific notation with procedural fluency

clarifications.text: Instruction includes understanding that when adding or subtracting numbers in scientific notation, the exponents must be the same.
Instruction includes the use of appropriate tools and techniques.

MA.8.NSO.1.6.title: Solve real-world problems involving operations with numbers expressed in scientific notation

clarifications.text: Instruction includes the use of appropriate tools and techniques.
Within this benchmark, it is not the expectation to perform calculations by hand for numbers in scientific notation; calculators can be used.

MA.8.NSO.1.6.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.NSO.1.7.title: Solve multi-step mathematical and real-world problems involving the order of operations with rational numbers including exponents and radicals

clarifications.text: Instruction includes positive and negative rational numbers.
Within this benchmark, it is the expectation for exponents to be limited to integer exponents from -10 to 10 and radicals to be square roots or cube roots.
Refer to Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality (Appendix D).

MA.8.NSO.1.7.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts
appendix_references: Appendix D: Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality

MA.8.AR.1.1.title: Apply the Laws of Exponents to generate equivalent algebraic expressions, limited to integer exponents and monomial bases

clarifications.text: Instruction includes applying the Laws of Exponents to numerical and algebraic bases.
Within this benchmark, it is the expectation to simplify expressions with integer exponents from -10 to 10.
Refer to Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality (Appendix D).

MA.8.AR.1.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts
appendix_references: Appendix D: Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality

MA.8.AR.1.2.title: Apply properties of operations to multiply two linear expressions with rational coefficients

clarifications.text: Instruction includes understanding the relationship between multiplying linear expressions and area models.
Refer to Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality (Appendix D).

MA.8.AR.1.2.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts
appendix_references: Appendix D: Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality

MA.8.AR.1.3.title: Rewrite the sum of two algebraic expressions having a common monomial factor as a common factor multiplied by the sum of two algebraic expressions

clarifications.text: Instruction focuses on the application of the distributive property.
Refer to Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality (Appendix D).

MA.8.AR.1.3.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts
appendix_references: Appendix D: Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality

MA.8.AR.2.1.title: Solve multi-step linear equations in one variable, with rational number coefficients. Include equations with variables on both sides

clarifications.text: Instruction includes the use of standard form of an equation, ax + b = c, where a, b and c are rational numbers.
Within this benchmark, the expectation is to include solutions that are rational numbers.
Instruction includes equations with one solution, no solution or infinitely many solutions.
Refer to Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality (Appendix D).

MA.8.AR.2.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts
appendix_references: Appendix D: Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality

MA.8.AR.2.2.title: Solve two-step linear inequalities in one variable and represent solutions algebraically and graphically

clarifications.text: Within this benchmark, the expectation is to include solutions that are rational numbers.
Instruction includes representing solutions on a number line and algebraically.
Instruction includes the understanding that if you multiply or divide both sides of an inequality by a negative number, the inequality sign reverses.
Refer to Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality (Appendix D).

MA.8.AR.2.2.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts
appendix_references: Appendix D: Properties of Operations, Equality and Inequality

MA.8.AR.2.3.title: Given an equation in the form of x² = p and x³ = q, where p is a whole number and q is an integer, determine the real solutions

clarifications.text: Instruction includes recognizing that squaring a number and taking the square root are inverse operations. Similarly, cubing a number and taking the cube root are inverse operations.
Within this benchmark, the expectation is to know that for x² = p, both the principal square root and its opposite are solutions if p > 0.

MA.8.AR.2.3.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.AR.3.1.title: Determine if a linear relationship is also a proportional relationship

clarifications.text: Instruction includes understanding that proportional relationships are linear relationships whose graph passes through the origin.
Instruction includes representing proportional relationships by equations of the form y = kx, and other linear relationships by equations of the form y = mx + b.

MA.8.AR.3.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.AR.3.2.title: Given a table, graph or written description of a linear relationship, determine the slope

clarifications.text: Instruction includes using triangles to illustrate slope.
Instruction includes making the connection that the slope is equivalent to the constant rate of change of a linear relationship and the constant of proportionality.

MA.8.AR.3.2.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.AR.3.3.title: Given a table, graph or written description of a linear relationship, write an equation in slope-intercept form

clarifications.text: Within this benchmark, the expectation is to write linear equations given slope and y-intercept, slope and a point, two points, x- and y-intercepts, or a graph.
Instruction includes cases where the slope is zero or undefined.

MA.8.AR.3.3.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.AR.3.4.title: Given a mathematical or real-world context, graph a two-variable linear equation from a written description, a table or an equation in slope-intercept form

clarifications.text: Within this benchmark, the expectation is to use appropriate titles, labels and scales.
Instruction includes cases where the slope is zero or undefined.

MA.8.AR.3.4.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.AR.3.5.title: Given a real-world context, determine and interpret the slope and y-intercept of a two-variable linear equation from a written description, a table, a graph or an equation in slope-intercept form

clarifications.text: Instruction focuses on making connections between slope as a rate of change in a real-world context and the constant rate of change of a linear function.
Instruction focuses on the understanding that the y-intercept is the value of y when x is zero, which is also referred to as the initial value.

MA.8.AR.3.5.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.AR.4.1.title: Given a system of two linear equations and a specified set of possible solutions, determine which ordered pairs satisfy the system of linear equations

clarifications.text: Instruction focuses on the understanding that the solution to a system of linear equations is the point of intersection when graphed.
Within this benchmark, students are not solving the system of linear equations. They are given a set of possible solutions and determine which ordered pair(s) make both equations true.

MA.8.AR.4.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.AR.4.2.title: Given a system of two linear equations represented graphically on the same coordinate plane, determine whether there is one solution, no solution or infinitely many solutions

clarifications.text: Instruction includes understanding that two lines can intersect at one point, intersect at all points or not intersect.
Instruction includes understanding that parallel lines have the same slope but different y-intercepts.

MA.8.AR.4.2.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.AR.4.3.title: Given a mathematical or real-world context, solve systems of two linear equations by graphing

clarifications.text: Instruction focuses on finding solutions by graphing with an emphasis on the reasonableness of solutions.
Within this benchmark, the expectation is not to solve systems algebraically.

MA.8.AR.4.3.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.F.1.1.title: Given a set of ordered pairs, a table, a graph or mapping diagram, determine whether the relationship is a function. Identify the domain and range of the relation

clarifications.text: Instruction includes understanding that a function is a relation where each element of the domain is paired with exactly one element of the range.
Instruction includes use of the Vertical Line Test.
Within this benchmark, the expectation is not to use function notation.

MA.8.F.1.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.F.1.2.title: Given a function defined by a graph or an equation, determine whether the function is a linear function. Given an input-output table, determine whether it could represent a linear function

clarifications.text: Within this benchmark, it is the expectation to understand that linear functions have a constant rate of change.
Within this benchmark, it is the expectation to know that linear functions graph as a non-vertical straight line.
Instruction includes recognizing and using the rate of change to identify linear functions.

MA.8.F.1.2.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.F.1.3.title: Analyze a real-world written description or graphical representation of a functional relationship between two quantities and identify where the function is increasing, decreasing or constant

clarifications.text: Instruction focuses on describing the behavior of a function.
Within this benchmark, the expectation is to use interval notation is not required.

MA.8.F.1.3.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.GR.1.1.title: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to solve mathematical and real-world problems involving unknown side lengths in right triangles

clarifications.text: Instruction includes using Pythagorean Theorem and its converse.
Instruction focuses on understanding that side c represents the hypotenuse.
Refer to K-12 Glossary (Appendix A).

MA.8.GR.1.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.GR.1.2.title: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to solve mathematical and real-world problems involving the distance between two points in a coordinate plane

clarifications.text: Instruction includes understanding how the Distance Formula is derived from the Pythagorean Theorem.
Refer to K-12 Glossary (Appendix A).

MA.8.GR.1.2.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.GR.1.3.title: Use the Triangle Inequality Theorem to determine if a triangle can be formed from a given set of sides. Use the converse of the Pythagorean Theorem to determine if a right triangle can be formed from a given set of sides

clarifications.text: Instruction includes understanding that the Triangle Inequality Theorem states that the sum of the lengths of any two sides of a triangle must be greater than the length of the third side.
Refer to K-12 Glossary (Appendix A).

MA.8.GR.1.3.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.GR.1.4.title: Solve mathematical problems involving the relationships between supplementary, complementary, vertical or adjacent angles

clarifications.text: Instruction includes understanding the relationships between angles, including linear pairs.
Refer to K-12 Glossary (Appendix A).

MA.8.GR.1.4.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.GR.1.5.title: Solve problems involving the relationships of interior and exterior angles of a triangle

clarifications.text: Instruction includes understanding that the sum of the interior angles of a triangle is 180°.
Instruction includes understanding the Exterior Angle Theorem, which states that the measure of an exterior angle is equal to the sum of the measures of the two non-adjacent interior angles.
Refer to K-12 Glossary (Appendix A).

MA.8.GR.1.5.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.GR.1.6.title: Develop and use formulas for the sums of the interior angles of regular polygons by decomposing them into triangles

clarifications.text: Instruction includes deriving the formula (n - 2) × 180°, where n is the number of sides.
Refer to K-12 Glossary (Appendix A).

MA.8.GR.2.1.title: Given a preimage and image generated by a single transformation, identify the transformation that describes the relationship

clarifications.text: Instruction includes recognizing transformations both on and off a coordinate plane.
Transformations include translations, reflections, rotations and dilations.
Refer to K-12 Glossary (Appendix A).

MA.8.GR.2.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.GR.2.2.title: Given a preimage and image generated by a single dilation, identify the scale factor that describes the relationship

clarifications.text: Instruction includes understanding that the scale factor is the ratio of a side length of the image to the corresponding side length of the preimage.
Instruction includes determining if a dilation is an enlargement or reduction.
Refer to K-12 Glossary (Appendix A).

MA.8.GR.2.2.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.GR.2.3.title: Describe and apply the effect of a single transformation on two-dimensional figures using coordinates and the coordinate plane

clarifications.text: Transformations include translations, reflections, rotations and dilations.
Instruction includes drawing images of figures after transformations on the coordinate plane.
Instruction includes understanding the relationship between transformations and coordinates.
Refer to K-12 Glossary (Appendix A).

MA.8.GR.2.3.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.GR.2.4.title: Solve mathematical and real-world problems involving proportional relationships between similar triangles

clarifications.text: Instruction focuses on the understanding that when two triangles are similar, the corresponding sides are proportional.
Instruction includes using AA (Angle-Angle) to establish similarity of two triangles.
Refer to K-12 Glossary (Appendix A).

MA.8.GR.2.4.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.DP.1.1.title: Given a set of real-world bivariate numerical data, construct a scatter plot or a line graph as appropriate for the context

clarifications.text: Instruction includes understanding that scatter plots are appropriate for bivariate numerical data that do not have a natural order and line graphs are appropriate for bivariate numerical data that have a natural order.
Within this benchmark, line graphs may be referred to as line plots or line charts.
Instruction includes using appropriate titles, labels and scales.

MA.8.DP.1.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.DP.1.2.title: Given a scatter plot within a real-world context, describe patterns of association

clarifications.text: Instruction includes describing patterns as positive or negative association, linear or non-linear association, or no association.
Instruction includes identifying outliers and clusters.

MA.8.DP.1.2.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.DP.1.3.title: Given a scatter plot with a linear association, informally fit a straight line

clarifications.text: Instruction focuses on fitting a trend line for a scatter plot that suggests a linear association.
Within this benchmark, the expectation is not to find the equation of the trend line, but to understand that a trend line is a good fit if it is close to most of the data points.

MA.8.DP.1.3.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.DP.2.1.title: Determine the sample space for a repeated experiment

clarifications.text: Instruction includes the use of tables, tree diagrams, systematic lists and counting principles.
Within this benchmark, the expectation is to represent all the possible outcomes from a repeated experiment.

MA.8.DP.2.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.DP.2.2.title: Find the theoretical probability of an event related to a repeated experiment

clarifications.text: Instruction includes representing probability as a fraction, percentage or decimal.
Within this benchmark, the expectation is to work with theoretical probabilities from repeated experiments.
Refer to Probability (Appendix E).

MA.8.DP.2.2.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.8.DP.2.3.title: Solve real-world problems involving probabilities related to single or repeated experiments, including making predictions based on theoretical probability

clarifications.text: Instruction includes using simulations and relative frequencies as estimates of probabilities.
Instruction includes making predictions and validating or refuting them.
Refer to Probability (Appendix E).

MA.8.DP.2.3.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.K12.MTR.1.1.category: MTR.1 - Actively participate in effortful learning
MA.K12.MTR.1.1.title: Actively participate in effortful learning both individually and collectively

clarifications.text: Mathematicians who participate in effortful learning both individually and with others: Analyze the problem in a way that makes sense given the task; Ask questions that will help with solving the task; Build perseverance by modifying methods as needed while solving a challenging task; Stay engaged and maintain a positive mindset when working to solve tasks; Help and support each other when attempting a new method or approach.

MA.K12.MTR.1.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.K12.MTR.2.1.title: Demonstrate understanding by representing problems in multiple ways

clarifications.text: Mathematicians who demonstrate understanding by representing problems in multiple ways: Build understanding through modeling and using manipulatives; Represent solutions to problems in multiple ways using objects, drawings, tables, graphs and equations; Progress from modeling problems with objects and drawings to using algorithms and equations; Express connections between concepts and representations; Choose a representation based on the given context or purpose.

MA.K12.MTR.2.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

clarifications.text: Mathematicians who complete tasks with mathematical fluency: Select efficient and appropriate methods for solving problems within the given context; Maintain flexibility and accuracy while performing procedures and mental calculations; Complete tasks accurately and with confidence; Adapt procedures to apply them to a new context; Use feedback to improve efficiency when performing calculations.

MA.K12.MTR.4.1.title: Engage in discussions that reflect on the mathematical thinking of self and others

clarifications.text: Mathematicians who engage in discussions that reflect on the mathematical thinking of self and others: Communicate mathematical ideas, vocabulary and methods effectively; Analyze the mathematical thinking of others; Compare the efficiency of a method to those expressed by others; Recognize errors and suggest how to correctly solve the task; Justify results by explaining methods and processes; Construct possible arguments based on evidence.

MA.K12.MTR.4.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.K12.MTR.5.1.title: Use patterns and structure to help understand and connect mathematical concepts

clarifications.text: Mathematicians who use patterns and structure to help understand and connect mathematical concepts: Focus on relevant details within a problem; Create plans and procedures to logically order events, steps or ideas to solve problems; Decompose a complex problem into manageable parts; Relate previously learned concepts to new concepts; Look for similarities among problems; Connect solutions of problems to more complicated large-scale situations.

MA.K12.MTR.5.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.K12.MTR.6.1.title: Assess the reasonableness of solutions

clarifications.text: Mathematicians who assess the reasonableness of solutions: Estimate to discover possible solutions; Use benchmark quantities to determine if a solution makes sense; Check calculations when solving problems; Verify possible solutions by explaining the methods used; Evaluate results based on the given context.

MA.K12.MTR.6.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

MA.K12.MTR.7.1.category: MTR.7 - Apply mathematics to real-world contexts
MA.K12.MTR.7.1.title: Apply mathematics to real-world contexts

clarifications.text: Mathematicians who apply mathematics to real-world contexts: Connect mathematical concepts to everyday experiences; Use models and methods to understand, represent and solve problems; Perform investigations to gather data or determine if a method is appropriate; Redesign models and methods to improve accuracy or efficiency.

MA.K12.MTR.7.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

ELA.K12.EE.1.1.title: Cite evidence to explain and justify reasoning

clarifications.text: K-1 Students include textual evidence in their oral communication with guidance and support from adults. The evidence can consist of details from the text without naming the text. During 1st grade, students learn how to incorporate the evidence in their writing.

2-3 Students include relevant textual evidence in their written and oral communication. Students should name the text when they refer to it. In 3rd grade, students should use a combination of direct and indirect citations.

4-5 Students continue with previous skills and reference comments made by speakers and peers. Students cite texts that they've directly quoted, paraphrased, or used for information. When writing, students will use the form of citation dictated by the instructor or the style guide referenced by the instructor.
6-8 Students continue with previous skills and use a style guide to create a proper citation.

ELA.K12.EE.1.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

ELA.K12.EE.2.1.title: Read and comprehend grade-level complex texts proficiently

clarifications.text: See Text Complexity for grade-level complexity bands and a text complexity rubric.

ELA.K12.EE.3.1.title: Make inferences to support comprehension

clarifications.text: Students will make inferences before the words infer or inference are introduced. Kindergarten students will answer questions like 'Why is the girl smiling?' or make predictions about what will happen based on the title page. Students will use the terms 'infer' and 'inference' once they are introduced in grade 4.

ELA.K12.EE.3.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

ELA.K12.EE.4.1.title: Use appropriate collaborative techniques and active listening skills when engaging in discussions in a variety of situations

clarifications.text: In kindergarten, students learn to listen to one another respectfully.
In grades 1-2, students build upon these skills by justifying what they are thinking. For example: 'I think X is true because...'
In grades 3-12, students learn to engage in discourse around a topic, text, or issue.

ELA.K12.EE.5.1.title: Use the accepted rules governing a specific format to create quality work

clarifications.text: Students will incorporate skills learned into work products that are formal and meet course-specific expectations.

ELA.K12.EE.5.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

ELA.K12.EE.6.1.title: Use appropriate voice and tone when speaking or writing

clarifications.text: In kindergarten and 1st grade, students learn the difference between formal and informal language. For example, the way we talk to our friends differs from the way we speak to adults. In 2nd grade and beyond, students practice appropriate social and academic language to discuss texts.

ELA.K12.EE.6.1.cognitive_complexity: Level 2: Basic Application of Skills & Concepts

categories.name: NSO.1 - Rational and Irrational Numbers
categories.focus: Rational and irrational numbers, laws of exponents, scientific notation, order of operations

categories.name: AR.1 - Algebraic Expressions
categories.focus: Laws of exponents with algebraic expressions, multiplying linear expressions, factoring

categories.name: AR.2 - Equations and Inequalities
categories.focus: Multi-step linear equations and inequalities, square and cube root equations

categories.name: AR.3 - Linear Relationships
categories.focus: Proportional vs. linear relationships, slope, slope-intercept form, graphing, interpretation

categories.name: AR.4 - Systems of Equations
categories.focus: Identifying solutions to systems, determining number of solutions, solving by graphing

categories.name: F.1 - Understanding Functions
categories.focus: Identifying functions, domain and range, linear vs. non-linear, function behavior

categories.name: GR.1 - Pythagorean Theorem and Angles
categories.focus: Pythagorean Theorem, distance formula, Triangle Inequality Theorem, angle relationships, interior/exterior angles, polygon angles

categories.name: GR.2 - Transformations and Similarity
categories.focus: Identifying transformations, scale factors, coordinate transformations, similar triangles

categories.name: DP.1 - Bivariate Data
categories.focus: Scatter plots, line graphs, patterns of association, line of best fit

categories.name: DP.2 - Probability
categories.focus: Sample space for repeated experiments, theoretical probability, real-world probability problems

Mathematical Thinking and Reasoning.focus: Effortful learning, multiple representations, mathematical fluency, mathematical discussions, patterns and structure, reasonableness, real-world applications

K-12 General Expectations.focus: Citing evidence, reading complex texts, making inferences, collaboration, quality work, voice and tone

instructional_notes.course_description: The fundamental purpose of M/J Grade 8 Pre-Algebra is to formalize and extend the mathematics that students learned in grades 6 and 7. This course deepens and extends understanding of linear and exponential relationships by contrasting them with each other and by applying linear models to data that exhibit a linear trend. Students engage in methods for analyzing, solving, and using quadratic functions. The Mathematical Thinking and Reasoning (MTR) standards specify the kind of thinking that students should engage in throughout all courses.
instructional_notes.mathematical_practices: The Mathematical Thinking and Reasoning (MTR) standards are embedded throughout all mathematics courses and should be integrated into instruction daily. These practices emphasize process standards that demonstrate how students should engage with mathematical content.
instructional_notes.key_transitions: Grade 8 Pre-Algebra represents the critical bridge to high school algebra, where students transition from arithmetic thinking to algebraic thinking, develop deep understanding of functions, and prepare for advanced mathematics including Algebra 1, Geometry, and beyond.
instructional_notes.technology_integration: Throughout this course, technology should be used appropriately to support instruction, assessment, and student exploration of mathematical concepts. Students should use graphing calculators, computer algebra systems, spreadsheets, and dynamic geometry software when appropriate.
instructional_notes.assessment_expectations: Students should demonstrate proficiency with rational and irrational numbers, scientific notation, laws of exponents, linear equations and inequalities, systems of equations, functions, Pythagorean Theorem, transformations, similarity, bivariate data analysis, and probability.
